pros: awesome place, great people, love the campus
cons: not any that i can think of doesnt get much betted

pros: Lots of PTO and sick time.
cons: There is a lot of lip service paid about how much they appreciate members of facilities maintenance, but in the end their actions are highly disrespectful of those doing the hard work of keeping the infrastructure running. Continually attempting to expand job descriptions to force its work force to perform tasks and provide staffing for functions they never signed up for. There was nothing in any of our position descriptions about HVAC techs, plumbers, electricians, or carpenters coming on the weekend to clean up trash for graduation ceremonies, and yet every time those of us who refused to "volunteer" were told it was our job work it and they would just stop just short of threatening our employment.

pros: good place to work and school

pros: Good Research Experience at CofC

pros: - Good mission to support students - Beautiful, historic campus in downtown Charleston

review_title: Nice colleagues and students are pretty good, but pay is abysmally low and cost of living high
pros: Flexible schedule, nice colleagues, beautiful city.
cons: Terrible pay and benefits. Retirement plans are mediocre and College doesn't match contributions. Good job if you have family money to supplement the cost of living but not realistic if you have to support yourself, much less kids or a spouse.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Charleston, SC
pros: Partnering with various departments on campus
cons: Some staff members are averse to change.

job_title: Full Time Adjunct Professor in Charleston, SC
pros: Had access to facilities in the art department. Inspiring being around the students who were actually interested in art. Met some great people in the department.
cons: Pay was atrocious. Absolutely no room for advancement. If a full time position comes available, I think you actually have less of a chance of getting the job if a full if you're an adjunct at the institution hiring. This isn't new news to anyone who has been an adjunct though. I'd say it's the norm everywhere in higher education. Although most of my dealings were pleasant with the chairs during my time at C of C, you were definitely treated differently than full time faculty. Even though I taught a 4 /4 most of my time at C of C, and had a better rapport with students than the head of my department, I was always treated as if I were expendable, and should be lucky to have the hours. If I'm being honest I knew there was no room for advancement after my first or second year, but I actually enjoyed being around students who enjoyed making and talking about art. I probably stayed too long, and thats on me, but something has to be done about the state of adjuncts and their place in higher education.

job_title: Student Peer Facilitator in Charleston, SC
pros: Very positive and enthusiastic work environment! Great job working as a student.
cons: There are no cons to this job.

review_title: Overworked and underpaid - a higher education story
pros: Prestige in the job, getting to work with young adults, decent state benefits (if you are able to get a "permanent employee" classification), and a beautiful campus.
cons: Nearly 1/3 - 1/2 of the staff employed are considered "temporary" employees despite being full time for several years and do not receive the same benefits. Pay is very poor across the board and does not compare to other state universities, even in SC. Poor leadership across many departments.

cons: I started working here during COVID and it never got too chaotic as I have heard it was in the past. A con may be that there is a lack of dialogue between incoming students/parents with Admissions though I do not put that blame on Admissions. They go above and beyond to reach out but there are times where visits and organization got confusing.

pros: Location, student body, some lovely people on staff, especially cleaning and maintenance staff (who are treated very poorly, btw).
cons: Staff can be very lazy and incompetent and still keep their job. If you did not cultivate "relationships" forget about getting people to do their jobs. For too many years, (men) upper administrators were arrogantly incompetent and made things very difficult for anyone with a fresh idea. I understand it's worse now. It was an old boys' club. At CofC still, "who you know" is everything. Be male and white, conservative, act subservient to the higher ups, forget your morals and values, and hey, you're promoted fairly quickly. Women were punished for an assertive management style while men were often rewarded for passive-aggressive behavior. However, if women did go along with the status quo, and did not push back against incompetent men, flattered and flirted, they too would eventually be rewarded. This created incompetent women leaders as well. Many took this exact path to success: deceive to advance. Also, if you happened to be white, young and good-looking, you could be an idiot and succeed to associate director level. Lot of inbreeding, hiring sweet, young CofC grads with connections over professionals.

review_title: Not a good place to work or attend
pros: vacation and holidays off - benefits are good
cons: don't care about employees or students dishonest bullying

review_title: It was overall ok, some great parts and some not so great parts
job_title: Coordinator, Student Services in Charleston, SC
pros: Great perks (employee discounts, free transit passes, etc) and a relaxed workplace atmosphere.  All of the offices are located near Marion Square Park, mass transit stops, great restaurants, and in the center of town.
cons: Salaries are low (even for the area which is notorious for low paying jobs) unless you are in upper management.  The mid level managers there are a mixed bag, some are fantastic (effective, smart, proactive) while unfortunately others are just terrible, either bad hires or lazy lifers on the public dole with no foresight and no ambition for change.

review_title: Good people, poor salaries and benefits
pros: The faculty and staff here are passionate and approachable; these people are what make this institution unique because undergraduates can do research and form bonds with the professors that lead their fields. Good advising and excellent study abroad opportunities. Located in historic and beautiful downtown Charleston.
cons: The health benefits as a employee in this institution, which are state-run, are laughable.  Cost of living very high with lower wages than the industry average. No raises ever -- not even including any bumps for inflation costs.  Increased meter parking costs and also parking costs for faculty which are upwards of $750 per year out of pocket. Some departments employ numerous yearly-contracted adjunct faculty members instead of opening roster positions for these qualified and highly motivated individuals.

review_title: Not a place to work long-term!
pros: The best reason to work for College of Charleston is to have an income while you search for other jobs.  The college does have a generous leave policy.  It's about the best thing about the job.  Also, working at the college provides a good networking opportunity.  I used my time at the college to network and make a name for myself for the future.  I used them as much as they used me!
cons: Employer expects you to do more work than listed on your position description.  For your annual review, they add duties to your position description but do not give you an increase in pay.  I had a perfect review and did not receive a merit pay increase; instead, I received additional duties I was responsible for.

review_title: Wonderful people, beautiful campus, your experience depends on your position and department
pros: Good culture of promoting within, providing opportunities to grow and lots of protection as state employee.  The campus is beautiful, the people are great and it's a wonderful College to work for.  Open minded and supportive environment.
cons: As a state employee, there is little room for growth in salary (though plenty in responsibilities), raises are minimal and there are strict regulations regarding pay that HR has to keep to, so if you're looking for a well paying job at an entry or mid level, this isn't the place.  Senior staff members enjoy respectable salaries, but the "little" people - not so much.

pros: College of Charleston has a beautiful campus and friendly employees. Employees have a Generous leave policy with extended time off during holidays. Most departments have a very casual atmosphere. Great place to make professional connections. Administrators and senior professors generally are compensated  well. Employees can ride public bus system for free and may take 1 free class per semester. Funds are available for attending professional conferences and technology.
cons: Non teaching employees generally are paid much less than peers that work at other state assisted  institutions or agencies. Employees must pay for parking. Insurance coverage is mediocre. Salary raises are rare and meager. Institution is top-heavy with administrators. Career advancement  is not possible in many departments. There are many lean budget years as the school depends on the conservative state government for much of its funding.

pros: I worked as a staff member at the College of Charleston for 4 years, both as a student worker and as a professional staff member. The people I worked with in Student Affairs and Academic Affairs were incredibly dedicated to the student experience. I was able to collaborate across multiple departments to create programs that would benefit all students.
cons: There are a lot of temporary positions on campus, which means no benefits and no paid time off. This made it extremely difficult to afford living in Charleston and it was one of the biggest factors in my departure.

review_title: Could be a great department to work for but...
job_title: Public Safety Officer in Charleston, SC
pros: Working with a few good people
cons: Lack of Communication, Overworked, Not Enough Man Power, Weak Leadership from Command Staff

pros:
-Half off housing
-$11.55/hr pay
-Great location
-Being able to get to know many different students
-Networking
cons:
-Only paid for 5 hours a week (when you sit at the front desk), though are on-call 12 hours once a week or every two weeks, have to organize 3 different programs a month, and have to decorate the hall WITH NO PAY FOR THESE TASKS
-Lack of communication from director that trickles down to hall director
-Lack of caring that we are students before RAs
-Must volunteer for events that you are no made aware about
-Over worked and under paid

job_title: Pubic Safety Officer in Charleston, SC
pros: Great Start for a Law Enforcement Job.  Supervisors and Co-workers are a pleasure to work with.  Police Pension Plan is one of the best.  Long work schedules, but every other weekend is a 3 day weekend.  Plenty of Overtime.
cons: High turnover rate.  Medical Benefits are not good.  Everybody has to pay for Parking and a Meal Plan if you want to eat on Campus.  Parking plans a bit pricey.  During the Day there is no where to park on the streets while on Campus.

review_title: Center for student learning tutor, good position for college student wanting to earn money
pros: help people, make your own hours, get your own work done. culture is great, employees are nice and helpful. Willing to work around your schedule
cons: gets really busy, students can be mean. They do not pay that much. no real training or refreshing of the subjects in which they expect you to tutor

review_title: Good but could be much better
pros: Nice campus, good students, nice classroom sizes.  The university has attracted faculty who are passionate teachers particularly of undergraduate students.
cons: Poor leadership.  An excess of top down accountability from all level of administration; however administration fends off at all cost placing its record under the microscope.  As a result there is a widening gap between faculty/staff and administration (all levels).

pros: Completely willing to work around your schedule, trust and respect, the ability to manage my own time. Fun and fast paced.
cons: The budget of the different departments is highly skewed and it's really disappointing see certain ones get denied something when others can get anything they want.

review_title: It's a great place for faculty and no one else.
pros: Very friendly, flexible, easy, not too repetitive, many people work this position for their life times
cons: Personally, the research was interesting but after a while became slow moving. If you enjoy a wide range of issues this may not be the place for you as the work tends to be specialized.

review_title: You have to like your job to work here
pros: Students, Grounds, Staff and Faculty, Bus
cons: Pay is low, does not keep up with cost of living. Increases often in the form of 1-time bonuses. Money goes into programming benefitting few. Limited  work schedule flexibility.

review_title: The Research Environment at the College of Charleston
job_title: SURF Grant Recipient and CSL Tutor in Charleston, SC
pros:
Stipends are tax-free!

Flexible hours.

Clients are friendly, and the work environment is not incredibly competitive.

Campus organization feels like a private college though it is considered public.
cons:
Not very knowledgeable.

Advances in training don't mean very large raises in hourly wages.

pros: Beautiful campus, many awesome coworkers, great benefits.
cons: I have worked under 5 administrations, and this one is by far the worst. There are way too many chiefs and not enough Indians! I have experienced hostile work environments, harassment from superiors, pay discrimination, and almost constant hurtles to get work done. The Good Ole Boy system has existed through each administration.

pros: The college is well run.  Many senior level VPs which ensures all bases are covered however it seems as if you work for 10 people at times.
cons: Micromanagement is at times a problem due to high number of supervisors.  Expensive city to live in.  Streets flood a lot.

review_title: Your experience depends on who you are.
pros: A great stepping stone into a fulfilling career elsewhere.
cons:
It is entirely too political with little regard for the needs of the students, but rather the desires of the upper-level management.
Has little to no regard for needs of diverse students (and I don't just mean Jewish).
Temporary workers are treated very poorly and paid very poorly while the athletic director makes 400k annually.

pros: Great location downtown, working with great professors/undergrad students, and . Poster fairs and presentations are always fun.
cons: Funding can be a nightmare--less qualified people get SURF (Summer Undergraduate Research Funding), MAYS (Major Academic Year Support) from CofC over you if there project is more 'interesting'. Funding seems to be random and just based on the project title not actually the work involved.

review_title: career peak- if your career goal is to be an administrative assistant, then this is a great place
pros: Very friendly, flexible, easy, not too repetitive, many people work this position for their life times
cons: no promotions for admins, sitting at a desk for many hours a day

pros: the staff is wonderful, you receive lots of teaching instruction and help. Kind work environment.
cons: Pretty low pay concerning the intensity of the work you do. I was often expected to manage students with learning disabilities and anxiety disorders that I was not equipped to do. I had to take a student to the hospital once, and still was only paid $10/hr with a max of 7 hrs a week.

pros: Good benefits and lots of time off.  Slower pace than most corporate jobs.
cons: Things move too slow in most areas.  Under funded in many areas.  Raises are rare and when they do happen they are minimal.  If you don't start with higher than usual pay -- you will never get enough in raises to "catch up".

review_title: Ok, not much aimed towards diversity.
pros: Location is in the center of downtown and shopping areas. Great access to cabs and Ubers. Party central, always booming on the weekends.
cons: Improper representation of people of color and what best suits them. Lack of inclusion of diverse events for those who need the help.

pros: Great colleagues with most heavily involved with initiatives for continuous improvement.  Very student focused.   Strong teaching and learning center.  Encourages students to do study abroad.
cons: Research expectations but with virtually no support.  Student credentials diminishing.  Almost no state financial support but heavily regulated.

pros: I'm very fortunate in that my department is absolutely sensational. Lots of good, hard-working people who want to be great at what they do. I am very fortunate.
cons: So. Much. Red. Tape. Comes with working for the state. Also, very limited opportunities for salary increases and advancement. I see this as a stepping stone, not an end-goal.

review_title: Backwards thinking in regards to what's important
pros: Great learning environment. Lots of activities on campus to participate in. Great location.
cons: Some classes, teachers, and ideas are not living in the real world. Too much theoretical teaching, not enough real world teachings.

pros: Normal business hours for most positions, regular schedule, great support from campus community
cons: No extra "employee benefits." Can sometimes be hard to schedule class and job because they're often during the same hours.
